titleStmt.title: [Photograph of a carved steatite (soapstone) pipe excavated at the former site of the mid-18th century Cherokee town of Chota, taken in 1969] / [by George Fielder]: a machine-readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Fielder, George

availability.p: This work is the property of the McClung Museum, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN. It may be used freely by individuals for research, teaching, and personal use as long as this statement of availability is included in the text.

bibl.title: [Photograph of a carved steatite (soapstone) pipe excavated at the former site of the mid-18th century Cherokee town of Chota, taken in 1969] / [by George Fielder]
bibl.author: Fielder, George
bibl.note: This is a photograph of a mid-18th century Cherokee carved steatite (soapstone) pipe that was excavated at the site of Chota in 1969. Chota was recognized by Native Americans and European settlers as a powerful social and economic influence and was regarded as the capital of the Cherokee nation. Excavations of Chota and other Overhill villages were conducted by the University of Tennessee as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Alfred K. Guthe. Field Director, J. Worth Greene.
Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

projectDesc.p: Prepared for The University of Tennessee Digital Library

figure.figDesc: Carved steatite (soapstone) pipe, Cherokee, mid-18th century. Excavated at Chota, 1969. Photograph by George Fielder. This information was provided by the Frank H. McClung Museum.
